articles.headline: Citigroup Posts $2.5 Billion Loss on Write-Downs
articles.snippet: Citigroup’s chief executive positioned the loss, largely caused by $7.2 billion of loan write-downs, as progress.
articles.abstract: Citigroup’s chief executive positioned the loss, largely caused by $7.2 billion of loan write-downs, as progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hobbled by the credit crisis at home, Citigroup has limped through nine months in the red, reporting a $2.5 billion quarterly loss on Friday.

articles.headline: To Save Gas, Shoppers Stay Home and Click
articles.snippet: A number of retailers are experiencing double-digit sales growth on their shopping Web sites at a time when simply filling up a gas tank to head to the mall can seem like a spending spree.
articles.abstract: A number of retailers are experiencing double-digit sales growth on their shopping Web sites at a time when simply filling up a gas tank to head to the mall can seem like a spending spree.
articles.lead_paragraph: To go shopping these days, more Americans are trading in their car keys for a keyboard.

articles.headline: Costly Toys, or a New Era for Drivers?
articles.snippet: The chief backer of the Tesla Roadster, the first-ever all-electric sports car with a base price of $109,000, believes that the age of the electric car has dawned.
articles.abstract: The chief backer of the Tesla Roadster, the first-ever all-electric sports car with a base price of $109,000, believes that the age of the electric car has dawned.
articles.lead_paragraph: “In and of itself,” said Elon Musk, “a $100,000 sports car is not going to change the world.”

articles.headline: A Veil Closes France’s Door to Citizenship
articles.snippet: The case of a woman with a veil has sharpened France’s focus on balancing secularism and freedom of religion.
articles.abstract: The case of a woman with a veil has sharpened France’s focus on balancing secularism and freedom of religion.
articles.lead_paragraph: LA VERRIÈRE, France  When Faiza Silmi applied for French citizenship, she worried that her French was not quite good enough or that her Moroccan upbringing would pose a problem.

articles.headline: Honor Your Word, or This Banker May Call Mom
articles.snippet: A look at the local community bank, where bankers try to make prudent loans within the community and try to keep customers from making a mess of their finances.
articles.abstract: A look at the local community bank, where bankers try to make prudent loans within the community and try to keep customers from making a mess of their finances.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, it was easy to write off the local community bank as a relic, a quaint reminder of an age when you actually needed to visit a branch to manage your money.

articles.headline: Bush, in a Shift, Accepts Concept of Iraq Timeline
articles.snippet: President Bush’s concession reflected both progress in stabilizing Iraq and the depth of opposition in both countries to an open-ended U.S. military presence.
articles.abstract: President Bush’s concession reflected both progress in stabilizing Iraq and the depth of opposition in both countries to an open-ended U.S. military presence.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON  President Bush agreed to “a general time horizon” for withdrawing American troops in Iraq, the White House announced Friday, in a concession that reflected both progress in stabilizing Iraq and the depth of political opposition to an open-ended military presence in Iraq and at home.

articles.headline: Trading in Soccer Talent
articles.snippet: Brazilian companies are engaging in a new and controversial wave of investment by buying up contracts of young soccer players and lending the players to teams.
articles.abstract: Brazilian companies are engaging in a new and controversial wave of investment by buying up contracts of young soccer players and lending the players to teams.
articles.lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  Some co-workers are sitting around their office here on a recent Monday afternoon, dissecting the weekend’s soccer matches and picking their top players.

articles.headline: Stock Markets Pause After 2-Day Rally
articles.snippet: Indexes were mixed as investors weighed an increase in oil prices against better-than-expected earnings from Citigroup.
articles.abstract: Indexes were mixed as investors weighed an increase in oil prices against better-than-expected earnings from Citigroup.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks muddled through a mixed session on Friday, ending a tumultuous week on a quiet note.

articles.headline: Felons Seeking Bush Pardon Near a Record
articles.snippet: Inmates are asking for pardons in a period when other presidents have granted a flurry of clemency requests.
articles.abstract: Inmates are asking for pardons in a period when other presidents have granted a flurry of clemency requests.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Felons are asking President Bush for pardons and commutations at historic levels as he nears his final months in office, a time when many other presidents have granted a flurry of clemency requests.

articles.headline: In Dispute With BP, Kremlin’s Hand Is Seen
articles.snippet: Critics say that Russian shareholders have enlisted an improbable ally in their attempt to force BP to fire the chief executive of TNK-BP.
articles.abstract: Critics say that Russian shareholders have enlisted an improbable ally in their attempt to force BP to fire the chief executive of TNK-BP.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  BP’s billionaire Russian oil partners have characterized their dispute with the British oil giant as a shareholder revolt  in the spirit of Kirk Kerkorian’s hounding General Motors or Carl C. Icahn holding Yahoo’s feet to the fire.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Alone in Rejecting All Evidence if Police Err
articles.snippet: No other country goes as far as the U.S. in excluding evidence from trials because of official misconduct.
articles.abstract: No other country goes as far as the U.S. in excluding evidence from trials because of official misconduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bradley Harrison was driving a rented Dodge Durango from Vancouver to Toronto in the fall of 2004 with 77 pounds of cocaine in the trunk when a police officer pulled him over, found the drugs and arrested him.

articles.headline: Obama’s Visit Renews Focus on Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Barack Obama stopped on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with John McCain.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama stopped on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with John McCain.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Senator Barack Obama arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday, on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with Senator John McCain over whether the war in Iraq has been a distraction in hunting down terrorists.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Given a Shovel, Americans Dig Deeper Into Debt
articles.snippet: Practices that produced record profits for many banks have led millions of Americans to the brink.
articles.abstract: Practices that produced record profits for many banks have led millions of Americans to the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: The collection agencies call at least 20 times a day. For a little quiet, Diane McLeod stashes her phone in the dishwasher.

articles.headline: Borrowers and Bankers: A Great Divide
articles.snippet: The credit crisis has exacerbated a dangerous division between average borrowers and an elite slice of corporations, banks and executives enriched by the mortgage mania.
articles.abstract: The credit crisis has exacerbated a dangerous division between average borrowers and an elite slice of corporations, banks and executives enriched by the mortgage mania.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE credit crisis has exposed and worsened a dangerous and deepening divide in this country between a vast number of average borrowers and a fairly elite slice of corporations, banks and executives enriched by the mortgage mania.

articles.headline: Somali Killings of Aid Workers Imperil Relief
articles.snippet: Aid workers whom Somalis depend on are fleeing — driven out by what appears to be an organized terror campaign.
articles.abstract: Aid workers whom Somalis depend on are fleeing — driven out by what appears to be an organized terror campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya  At a time of drought, skyrocketing food prices, crippling inflation and intensifying street fighting, many of the aid workers whom millions of Somalis depend on for survival are fleeing their posts  or in some cases the country.

articles.headline: Western Olympic Ads Cheerlead for China
articles.snippet: Global corporations are appealing to nationalism in an advertising blitz the likes of which China has never seen.
articles.abstract: Global corporations are appealing to nationalism in an advertising blitz the likes of which China has never seen.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  It is becoming increasingly clear which nation global corporations will be rooting for at this summer’s Olympics: China.

articles.headline: Can Si Newhouse Keep Condé Nast’s Gloss Going?
articles.snippet: The chairman of Condé Nast defies the image of the media baron driven by love of the limelight, politics or money.
articles.abstract: The chairman of Condé Nast defies the image of the media baron driven by love of the limelight, politics or money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN the wizards at Condé Nast Publications recently marched a pre-press issue of Brides magazine through an in-house review, Si Newhouse, the company’s chairman, wondered aloud whether a few of the letters on the cover were a tad too close together.

articles.headline: Nuclear Talks With Iran End in a Deadlock
articles.snippet: The international talks included one of the most important diplomatic encounters between Iran and the U.S. since 1979.
articles.abstract: The international talks included one of the most important diplomatic encounters between Iran and the U.S. since 1979.
articles.lead_paragraph: GENEVA  International talks on Iran’s nuclear ambitions ended in deadlock on Saturday, despite the Bush administration’s decision to reverse policy and send a senior American official to the table for the first time.

articles.headline: Obama Opens a Foreign Tour in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama began a high-stakes foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with John McCain in the presidential campaign.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama began a high-stakes foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with John McCain in the presidential campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Senator Barack Obama arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday, opening a high-stakes foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with Senator John McCain in the presidential campaign over whether the war in Iraq has been a distraction in hunting down terrorists.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Needing a Star, CNBC Made One
articles.snippet: Erin Burnett’s meteoric rise is the most recent example of how television networks try to transform fresh-faced hosts into household names.
articles.abstract: Erin Burnett’s meteoric rise is the most recent example of how television networks try to transform fresh-faced hosts into household names.
articles.lead_paragraph: ONLY days into a new job at CNBC two and a half years ago, Erin Burnett was settling into orientation when the network decided to put her on camera.

articles.headline: On Mustang Range, a Battle on Thinning the Herd
articles.snippet: An emotional debate is raging in the West over whether to thin a captive herd of wild horses that numbers 30,000.
articles.abstract: An emotional debate is raging in the West over whether to thin a captive herd of wild horses that numbers 30,000.
articles.lead_paragraph: GERLACH, Nev.  Five mustangs pounded across the high desert recently, their dark manes and tails giving shape to the wind. Pursued by a helicopter, they ran into a corral  and into the center of the emotional debate over whether euthanasia should be used to thin a captive herd that already numbers 30,000.

articles.headline: After 2000 Run, McCain Learned to Work Levers of Power
articles.snippet: Once better known for criticizing the Senate than for influencing it, John McCain has evolved into perhaps the chamber’s most influential member.
articles.abstract: Once better known for criticizing the Senate than for influencing it, John McCain has evolved into perhaps the chamber’s most influential member.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain was all but a sworn enemy of Senator Trent Lott, the former Republican leader.

articles.headline: Trying to Save by Increasing Doctors' Fees
articles.snippet: Paying physicians to devote more time to their patients, insurers hope to scale back costly treatments later.
articles.abstract: Paying physicians to devote more time to their patients, insurers hope to scale back costly treatments later.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cutting health costs by paying doctors more?

articles.headline: Smaller PCs Cause Worry for Industry
articles.snippet: In a tale of sales success breeding resentment, computer firms are worried the new breed of computers’ low price could threaten already thin profit margins.
articles.abstract: In a tale of sales success breeding resentment, computer firms are worried the new breed of computers’ low price could threaten already thin profit margins.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  The personal computer industry is poised to sell tens of millions of small, energy-efficient Internet-centric devices. Curiously, some of the biggest companies in the business consider this bad news.

articles.headline: Mideast Facing Choice Between Crops and Water
articles.snippet: Amid global food shortages, the region is choosing between growing more crops or preserving a scant supply of water.
articles.abstract: Amid global food shortages, the region is choosing between growing more crops or preserving a scant supply of water.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Global food shortages have placed the Middle East and North Africa in a quandary, as they are forced to choose between growing more crops to feed an expanding population or preserving their already scant supply of water.

articles.headline: Trouble at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac Stirs Concern Abroad
articles.snippet: The government rescue of the housing giants will test the world’s faith in U.S. markets, as about one-fifth of the lenders’ securities are held by foreign investors.
articles.abstract: The government rescue of the housing giants will test the world’s faith in U.S. markets, as about one-fifth of the lenders’ securities are held by foreign investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the housing giants that make the American mortgage market run, have attracted overseas investors with a simple pitch: the securities they issue are just as good as the United States government’s, and they usually pay better.

articles.headline: Hey, Friend, Do I Know You?
articles.snippet: When a new media winner like Facebook comes over the horizon, who loses? In my case, it’s probably my real actual friends.
articles.abstract: When a new media winner like Facebook comes over the horizon, who loses? In my case, it’s probably my real actual friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not that long ago, I needed some advice on the book business and thought to ask my friend Buzz Bissinger, the author of “Friday Night Lights” and “A Prayer for the City.” The only sticking point was, we’d never met.

articles.headline: Networks Fight Shorter Olympic Leash
articles.snippet: A plan for 3,600 hours of coverage may collide with efforts to stifle news.
articles.abstract: A plan for 3,600 hours of coverage may collide with efforts to stifle news.
articles.lead_paragraph: For several years now NBC has meticulously planned all the details for its coverage of the many sports events at the Summer Olympics in China.

articles.headline: Where Racing Is Fast and Police Aren’t Furious
articles.snippet: Police officers in Lodz, Poland, have tried to deal with illegal street races by helping to organize them.
articles.abstract: Police officers in Lodz, Poland, have tried to deal with illegal street races by helping to organize them.
articles.lead_paragraph: LODZ, Poland  People drag-race on the main avenue here in broad daylight, and the police just stand by and watch. That is, until the commissioner steps up to hand trophies to the winners.

articles.headline: My Son, the Blogger: An M.D. Trades Medicine for Apple Rumors
articles.snippet: Dr. Arnold Kim’s Web site, MacRumors.com, has become such a popular technology site, he has stopped practicing medicine to blog full time.
articles.abstract: Dr. Arnold Kim’s Web site, MacRumors.com, has become such a popular technology site, he has stopped practicing medicine to blog full time.
articles.lead_paragraph: For eight years, Arnold Kim has been trading gossip, rumor and facts about Apple, the notoriously secretive computer company, on his Web site, MacRumors.com.

articles.headline: Influx of Voters Expected to Test New Technology
articles.snippet: Officials fear that new voting technologies paired with millions of new voters may cause the system to buckle.
articles.abstract: Officials fear that new voting technologies paired with millions of new voters may cause the system to buckle.
articles.lead_paragraph: With millions of new voters heading to the polls this November and many states introducing new voting technologies, election officials and voting monitors say they fear the combination is likely to create long lines, stressed-out poll workers and late tallies on Election Day.
